Title:
The enigmatic Cortinarius magellanicus complex occurring in
Nothofagaceae forests of the Southern hemisphere (Gondwanian region of
New Zealand and sub-Arctic region of Argentina and Chile)
Keywords:
Cortinarius janthinophaeus, Cortinarius cinereus,
Cortinarius lugubris, validation of Cortinarius semiamictus,
Nothofagus-associated Myxacium, Gondwanian biogeography
Abstract:
Cortinarius magellanicus Speg. is an edible,
ectomycorrhizal (EM) mushroom, which is usually consumed in Patagonia.
This beautiful fungus can be recognized by the conspicuously violet,
slender basidiomes, which are glutinous all over, as typical for
Cortinarius subgenus Myxacium. Spegazzini´s original material was lost;
for that reason, C. magellanicus was re-described and validated with a
neotype by Moser & Horak in 1975. Since then, Cortinarius
magellanicus was considered a living fossil of Nothofagaceae forests, as
it is the most frequent and widely distributed species of Cortinarius in
the Southern Hemisphere (Argentina, Chile and New Zealand). However, our
knowledge on Patagonian Cortinarius diversity is still poor and mainly
based on Moser & Horak´s work. Therefore, we carried out an
extensive sampling of Cortinarius species growing in Argentinian
Nothofagaceae forests during March to May 2017. These recent collections
recognized as C. magellanicus by classical morpho-anatomical characters
were used for a phylogenetic analysis based on rDNA ITS sequences.
Sequences from Cortinarius type material and closely related sequences
from GenBank are also included in the study. Our results showed that C.
magellanicus represents a complex of species composed of at least three
phylogenetic lineages, each with strong regionalism and distinct host
associations. This complex is closely related to C. janthinophaeus, with
dry pilei and stipe, thus being a typical representative of the subgenus
Telamonia. This highlights that, especially in the Southern Hemisphere,
many infrageneric groups of Cortinarius have the tendency to form a
glutinous layer on pileus and stipe. In South America C. magellanicus
ss. is restricted to sub-Antarctic regions of Argentina and Chile. The
records erroneously reported from New Zealand and Australia are
misidentified and represent distinct lineages. In the present
contribution the re-description of Cortinarius magellanicus Speg. is
based on Patagonian neotype material. Moreover, C. magellanicoalbus and
C. roblerauli are proposed as new species based on consistent
morpho-anatomical characters and the typical ecology of their habitats.
Cortinarius vitreopileatus var. similissimus is described as a new
variety for a taxon from New Zealand resembling C. magellanicus. A key
to the species, which morphologically resemble C. magellanicus is also
included. The taxonomic delimitation of the taxa belonging to the C.
magellanicus species complex is of high relevance due to the abundance
of these fungi, their ectomycorrhizal role and relationships in
Nothofagaceae forests in the sub-Antarctic regions of South America and
Australasia.
